With only a few commercial facilities,
is somewhere to get way from it all - especially for people interested in birdlife and archaeology. Locally, the island is known as "Papay", pronounced

. Currently there are about 70 resident inhabitants. It is a stunningly beautiful island, located at the north-western corner of the Orkney archipelago, with a very welcoming community - it makes for a delightful short visit, but the island has such depth and character that one could easily spend a quiet couple of weeks here - an experience which you will always remember.
Several passenger ferries a day link Papa Westray  with Pierowall on

Terminal building at Papa Westray airport

provide at least two flights each weekday (one on Sundays) between Papa Westray and
. The flight between Papa Westray and Westray is the shortest (2 minutes) scheduled flight in the world!

Distances on the island are deceptive. One hour of fast walking along the island's (very quiet) main road will take you from the new pier in the south to the edge of the RSPB North Hill reserve in the north. However, a complete circuit of the island's coast will take a full and fascinating day because of the much greater distance involved and the distractions of archaeological sites, scenery and birds and seals on the white sandy beaches.

value: File:St Boniface's Church, Papa Westray - geograph.org.uk - 1280025.jpg
is the oldest standing domestic structure in northern Europe, dating from about 3500BC.
in the centre of the island has a set of attractive buildings and a small free museum.

and see Arctic terns and other birds from the small hide.

has a superb display of the beautiful Scottish Primrose (Primula scotica), which can be seen in flower for a few weeks from mid May and again in July - however, this tiny plant can be hard to find and you must be careful to avoid disturbing sensitive breeding birds on the reserve, so contact the warden for information on exactly where to go. The twice-weekly guided walks are highly recommended!
every Wednesday morning in the new kirk guarantees delicious refreshment and is a great way to meet local folk.
